Dee-Ann has been engaged in the fishing business with her husband for almost more than 20 years now. This is the source of their income. Dee-Ann is asking to take a loan to buy a new boat engine, boat case and fishing nets. A loan will help them improve their business as well as their income.

loans.use: to buy a new boat engine, boat case and fishing nets.

loans.name: Rubi

texts.en:
Rubi is a 34-year-old married woman. She runs a beauty parlor and has been in business for three years. She offers many facilities to her customers, such as makeup, hair styling, and facials. Over time, she has attained a list of regular customers and makes enough to contribute to the family income.

She needs to deal with increasing customer demand, and so she requires hair care products, skin products, and bleaching and whitening creams in large quantities. Therefore, she applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR through Kashf Foundation.

She is in her sixth loan cycle and has a good repayment history. She is very experienced in her business and confident that her business will move in a positive direction as a result of this loan investment.

loans.use: to buy hair care products, skin products, and bleaching and whitening creams in large quantities

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 37 years old and lives in Oroquieta City, Philippines. She is married and has three school-aged children. For a living, Jane owns and operates a business providing transport to local community members, with her husband as the driver. She has been doing this for five years. Now, she has requested a loan to purchase a second-hand motorcab unit. This way, she will be able to earn additional income. In the future, Jane hopes to own more motorcar units so that she can help other drivers to earn an income as well for their own families.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand motorcab unit.

loans.name: Besar

texts.en: Besar is single and lives in the southern part of Kosovo with his entire family. His father works as a salesman and he is involved in agricultural work. Although his father is employed, it is with a very low salary and Besar is the main source of income for his family. He works very hard to help provide for his family and has a very positive outlook on his future. Currently he owns three goats from which he is able to sell milk and cheese in his area. At this time, he is requesting a loan in order to purchase another 15 goats and as a first time borrower, he is very excited about this opportunity. He is hoping to be able to expand his farm, allowing him to make more profit and financial ease for his family. Eventually he would like to even add cows to his farm. He is very grateful to the lenders and wants to thank them all.

loans.use: to purchase another 15 goats.

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en:
Marivel is married and has 7 kids. Her husband is a fisherman who never gets tired of supporting their big family. 

In 2000, Marivel applied for her membership to Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative. Hearing about all of the benefits of being a member, she didn't hesitate to join. She maintains herself as a credible member in good standing, and she always repays her loans in a timely manner. She was able to renovate her home out of her savings from her business. 

Recently, Marivel has requested a loan of 14,900 PHP in order to buy new fishing nets and accessories. She makes use of torn foam in their fish selling business and hopes to be able to buy new ones. Through this project, she believes she will be able to earn more income and expand their business. 

Marivel has found comfort in the financial help provided by Paglaum MPC, for which she gives thanks with all her heart.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and accessories.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia is a 47-year-old married woman. She works doing hand embroidery, making beautiful patterns for the people of her community. Her designs are much in demand and she has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to meeting the expenses of her home.

To help her continue her operations, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy spools of threads in different colors along with packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment. This purchase will allow her to cater to more customers consistently. She is hopeful that by satisfying more customers, she will get an increase in her income. She dreams for a bright future and desires to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy spools of threads in different colors along with packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment

loans.name: Elia

texts.en:
Elia is 35 years old. He is married with three children ranging in age from one to 10 years. Two of them go to school. He is a farmer and has been producing rice for 20 years. His wife is a businesswoman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers to grow rice and sell the rice. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow rice and sell the rice.

loans.name: Rex

texts.en: A fisherman from Carles, Iloilo, Rex is married with three children. He is 35 years old and has been in the fishing business for almost 18 years now. This is the sole source of his income. Rex is requesting a loan to buy new a boat engine and fishing nets. Rex believes that a loan will help him improve his business as well as his income

loans.use: to buy a new boat engine and fishing nets

loans.name: Johanna Carolina

texts.es:
Portoviejo es la capital de la provincia de Manabí en Ecuador. Conocida por ser la primera ciudad ecuatoriana más antigua asentada en la región costanera,  está  ganando terreno en el turismo ya que este cantón posee playa, ciudad y campo.
En este lugar vive la señora Johanna, tiene 26 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un hijo de 6 años que estudia el primer año básico. El cónyuge trabaja en una vulcanizadora, viven en casa de familiares.
Doña Johanna con la intención de ganarse algo por su cuenta y con esto  salir adelante en el hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa por catálogo, su forma de  ventas es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa, trabaja tres días a la semana  en las tardes ya que por las mañanas es impulsadora de ventas del Diario Manabita desde las 7h00  hasta 9h00 y en las tardes no tiene horario determinado para recorrer y hacer las ventas, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Tiene tres años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños. Está en el Grupo De Crédito hace seis años y le gustan las sesiones educativas y todos los beneficios que le brinda la fundación. Sus sueños es tener su casa propia ya que donde vive es de familiares.
texts.en:
Portoviejo is the capital of the province of Manabí in Ecuador. Known for being the oldest Ecuadorian city in the coastal region, it is gaining ground in the tourism industry because it has beaches, the city and countryside. 

This is where Johanna lives. She is 26 and in a relationship from which she has a 6-year-old son who is in his first year of primary school. Her partner works in a tyre shop and they live in a house belonging to family members.

In order to earn some money of her own accord which she can use to get ahead with the house, Johanna sells clothes from a catalogue, going door to door and also selling from her house. She works 3 days a week in the evenings because in the mornings she works as a sales driver at Diario Manabita from 7.00 to 9.00, and in the evenings she doesn't have a fixed timetable for travelling and making sales. Her clients use credit which she collects every 15 days. She has been doing this for 3 years and she really likes it. 

She is going to use this loan to buy more merchandise such as: trousers, blouses, t-shirts and children's clothes. She has been in the Credit Group for 6 years and she likes the educative sessions and all the benefits that the foundation offers. She dreams of having her own house as she currently lives with family.

loans.use: to buy trousers, blouses, t-shirts and children's clothing

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba is a creative woman who was born in 1979. She lives in a remote district. She is married and has two children. She is a seamstress, sewing traditional dresses for women.

Mahbuba is well known for her sewing skills and attracts a lot of satisfied and permanent clients from around her area. She likes her business. She wants to develop it and expand her productivity to improve her standard of living. She requested a 2,000 TJS loan for buying a new sewing machine.

Mahbuba hopes for and awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Denyse

texts.en:
Denyse is 31 years old, married and has a 1-year-old child. She is a farmer and has been producing rice for 14 years. Her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would buy more fertilizer to grow and sell rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children and to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to grow and sell rice.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es: Jorge vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, el se dedica a la agricultura siembra maíz desde hace 10 años, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, el está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con su trabajo y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Jorge lives in his own home along with his family. He is a farmer who has been growing corn for the past 10 years. Jorge sells his products at different markets that are located near his house.

He is requesting a loan in order to buy seeds, fertilizers, compost, pest controls, and other supplies so that he can improve the land that is shown in the photograph. As a result, he can continue his work and have more income.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, compost, pest controls, and other supplies in order to improve his land.

loans.name: Gairat

texts.en:
Gairat is a hard-working man. He was born in 1970. He is living in a remote district. He is married and has three children. 

Gairat is an honest, capable, patient, and helpful person. Every year he goes abroad to earn money, but in a foreign country he cannot earn enough money. He came home and worked on a domestic, collective farm as a farmer. Now he is keeping livestock and he sells in the domestic market. He is planning to improve his standard of living. 

Gairat is asking for financial support from Kiva to buy construction supplies in order to renovate his house. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to renovate his house.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase grains

loans.name: Akos

texts.fr: Akos est une femme veuve et âgée de 49 ans. Akos vit à Avédji avec deux de ses enfants et exerce son activité pour subvenir aux besoins quotidiens. Akos vend des poules et des canards à ses clients et suscite leur désir à passer assez de commandes. Akos s’approvisionne au marché quatre fois par mois et demande ce prêt pour acheter des canards qu’elle pourra revendre à de bons prix. Akos souhaite avoir une bonne rentabilité et aider ses enfants à s’épanouir.
texts.en: Akos is a widow, aged 49, who lives in Avédji  with two of her children. She has a business to support herself from day to day selling hens and ducks. She creates a want among her customers to place a fair number of orders. She gets her supplies at the market four times a month and is asking for this loan to purchase some ducks she will be able to resell at good prices. Akos would like to have a nice profit and help her children to thrive.

loans.use: to purchase 10 ducks

loans.name: Rizza

texts.en: Rizza is a 33-year-old married mother of four children from Carles, Iloilo. She operates a small sari-sari or convenience store business selling various goods to the people in her community. Rizza has been in the business for more than 10 years now. Her husband works as a fisherman. Rizza is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell like canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries. This loan will enable her to improve her inventory thus attracting more buyers in her store.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell like canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries.

loans.name: Ruhumba Tukore Group

texts.en:
Ruhumba Tukore Group is located along the main road of Ibanda-Mbarara road. The group is composed of mainly women who are married and widowed with a few single mothers.
Winnie is a widow who lost her husband in 2004. She was left with four children and she also takes care of her sisters’ two daughters who were abandoned by their mother. Winnie sells agricultural products like bananas. Besides that, she also has a small poultry farm where she gets income to boost her banana plantation. She is applying for a loan of UGX 300,000 through the group to buy small chicks for her poultry farm. She will use the rest of the money to pay school fees for her children. The proceeds will help her to meet the basic needs of life.
Her major challenge is insufficient capital to boost her business. Despite challenges Winnie has been able to provide good education and basic needs for her children. The group members appreciate the support of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy chicks.

loans.name: Basyam2 Group

texts.fr: Elise, membre représentatif est mère de 2 enfants tous scolarisés. Cette brave dame, fait le commerce du charbon du bois. Elise et les autres femmes sont à leur 8ème contrat de prêt avec notre institution mais elle font toujours des remboursements correctes. Elle a besoin du prêt pour acheter des sacs de charbon stocker pour vendre. Elise rend un service énorme à sa clientèle car beaucoup de ménages burkinabés utilisent encore le charbon de bois. A l'issue des ventes, elle aura un bénéfice qui lui permettra de s'occuper de ses enfants et de continuer son activité.
texts.en: Elise, a representative member, is the mother of two children, both in school. This good and honest woman does commerce in charcoal. She and the other women are on their 8th loan contract with the microfinance institution, and she always repays correctly. She needs the loan to purchase sacks of charcoal to stock up and then resell. Elise provides an enormous service to her customers, since many Burkina households still use charcoal. After making her sales, she will have a profit enabling her to take care of her children and to continue her business.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food for her restaurant.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
Rona is a 45-year-old married woman and the mother of eight children. She is from Carles, Iloilo and has been running a fishing business with her husband for more than 20 years now. This is the source of their income.

Rona is asking to take a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, a boat case, outriggers, and other fishing gear. Rona believes that a loan will help her improve her business as well as her income.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, lead weights, a  boat case, outriggers, and other fishing gear

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 48 years old. He is married with 3 children. He has had a business selling tyres and tubes for 5 years. 

He will be using the loan to purchase more tyres and tubes, and he hopes this will help him have a variety of tyres and tubes of several types for vehicles and thereby meet his customers' needs. This will also enable him to increase his income, which he will use to educate his children. 

His hopes and dreams for the future are to expand his business by opening another location.

loans.use: To buy tyres and tubes to sell to motorists and meet their needs and desires.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 45 years old. He is married with five children who are between 2 and 18 years old, 4 of whom go to school. He is a farmer and he has been producing rice for 24 years. Also his wife is a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizer. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land and to improve his welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers

loans.name: Rosa Candida

texts.es:
Rosa, no estudio, está casada y su pareja trabaja de jardinero, tiene tres hijos de los cuales dos viven con ella y el otro esta casado y tiene su propio hogar y trabaja.

Rosa, no tiene negocio, antes tenia una tienda en su casa. Su horario es todo el dia ya que trabaja en los oficios domesticos. 

Rosa, necesita el crédito para construir baños en su vivienda, le mejorara la condicion de vivienda y esto le permitira tener mejor calidad de vida.

Sus sueños son volver a poner la tienda para ayudar economicamente a su esposo en los gastos.
texts.en:
Rosa has not been to school. She is married and her husband works as a gardener. She has three children. Two of them live with her and one is married and has a home and a job. 

Rosa does not own a business. She used to have a store in her home. She works all day doing household chores. 

Rosa needs the loan to build bathrooms in her home. This will improve the home’s condition and better her quality of life.

Her dream is to reopen her store in order to help her husband financially with expenses

loans.use: To build bathrooms in her home.

loans.name: Jean D'amour

texts.en:
Jean D‘amour is 25 years old. He is married with one child who is 2 years old. He is a farmer and he has been producing rice for 10 years. Also his wife is a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizer to grow the rice and to sell it. The profits from the business will be used to buy seeds for rice production.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to grow rice and to sell it

loans.name: Otwisa's Group

texts.en:
Pictured above is Otwisa, often described as an extremely hardworking individual. He is 30 years old and, as a group leader, he is representing his group of 14 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya.  He is married and has one child.

Otwisa is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund again as this means that he is able to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, which is why he decided to join in the first place. Otwisa says that he is happy to have made that decision because, since he first joined in 2014, he has been able to save more money, which has improved his day-to-day life significantly. Otwisa will use the profits from this season to send his children to school.

The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 6.5 acres. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of 8 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 34 years old. She is married with two children who are 3 and 5 years old. One of them goes to school. 

She is a farmer and she has been producing rice for 13 years. Also her husband is a farmer. 

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy more fertilizer to grow rice and to sell it.  The profits from the business will be used to increase her savings

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer to grow rice and to sell it.

loans.name: Mablé

texts.fr: Agée de 40 ans, Mablé est une femme mariée et mère de trois enfants. Mablé habite à Avédji et vend des produits alimentaires dans une boutique à son domicile. Pour disposer du stock en permanence, Mablé s’approvisionne deux fois par mois au ghana. Mablé souhaite répondre favorablement aux attentes de ses clients qui désirent ses produits. Mablé demande ce crédit pour acheter des boites de tomates et des détergents et disposer d’une rentabilité pour couvrir ses charges quotidiennes
texts.en: Mablé is a 40-year old married woman and the mother of three. She lives in Avédji and sells grocery products from a store set up at her home. In order to keep running out of stock, Mablé stocks up twice a month in Ghana. She would like to be able to meet customer demand. Mablé is requesting this loan to buy canned tomatoes and detergents, so as to earn a profit margin and cover her everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy 12 packs of detergent and 15 cans of tomatoes.

loans.name: Bonita Luna Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad muy tranquila del centro de México, la mayoría de las personas se dedica al cultivo de papa aunque la tierra es ideal para casi cualquier tipo de producto y semilla por ser muy fértil. En este lugar se conformó un grupo de préstamo llamado Bonita Luna. 

Doña Juana es la líder del grupo, es una persona muy alegre y trababajora, tiene 50 años de edad y está casada con el señor Francisco  quien trabaja en el campo. Actualmente ya sólo 2 de sus hijos dependen de ellos y se encuentran estudiando la secundaria.

Doña Juanita, como es mejor conocida, inició una pequeña tienda de abarrotes hace 11 años. Recuerda que en aquél entonces no había tiendas en la comunidad y para adquirir cualquier producto básico era necesario caminar varios kilómetros además de que los habitantes no siempre encontraban específicamente lo que querían. Al principio, Juanita vendía sólo refrescos, huevo, leche, azúcar y algunos alimentos enlatados. Poco después escuchó hablar de VisionFund México y le pareció buena idea solicitar un crédito y usarlo junto con sus ahorros para comprar más productos. 

Con el paso del tiempo se volvió más común encontrar tiendas de abarrotes pero Juanita está decidida a seguir con su negocio porque le ayuda a solventar algunos gastos "No me gustaría que mis hijos dejaran de estudiar por falta de dinero". Juanita tuvo en total nueve hijos, los siete mayores sólo pudieron terminar la secundaria precisamente por la complicación de los gastos y definitivamente no quiere que la historia se repita con los más jóvenes.

Con el nuevo préstamo comprará leche, pan, huevo, refrescos y productos enlatados. Ella esta muy agradecida con VisionFund México porque ya ha recibido varios préstamos y con sus ganancias ha podido hacer mejoras a su casa e incrementar sus ganancias poco a poco. 

Las demás integrantes del grupo son Natalia, Angélica y Martha quienes invertirán en sus borregos, mientras que Doña Rosa María y Candelaria invertirán en pollos. 

*En la imagen: los integrantes en el jardín del centro del municipio donde viven. Doña Juanita es quien viste un suéter azul.
texts.en:
In a very peaceful community in the center of Mexico, most people cultivate potatoes (although the land is very fertile and ideal for any type of product or seed). The group Bonita Luna was created there.

Juana is the leader of the group. She is a 50-year old very cheerful and hard-working woman, who is married to Francisco, a farmer. Only two of their children currently depend on them, and they attend high school. Juanita, as most people call her, started a small grocery store 11 years ago. There were no stores in the community at that time, so people had to walk several km to buy any basic product. Moreover, people sometimes did not find what they were looking for. When she first started, Juanita sold sodas, eggs, milk, sugar and cans. She then heard about VisionFund Mexico and thought it would be a good idea to request a loan and use it with her savings to buy more products. Grocery stores became more popular later on, but Juanita has been determined to keep her business because it helps to cover some expenses. "I would not like my children to stop studying for financial reasons". Juanita had 9 children, 7 of whom stopped studying after high-school because of financial matters. She does not want this to happen with the youngest ones. 

She will use the new loan to buy milk, bread, eggs, sodas and cans. She is very grateful to VisionFund Mexico because she has received several loans and has been able to make improvements to her house and to increase earnings thanks to her higher income. 

Natalia, Angelica and Martha are other group members who will invest in their lambs. Rosa María and Candelaria will invest in chicken. 

*In the photo: all the group members in the building garden in the municipality where they live. Juanita is the one with a blue jacket.

loans.use: to buy milk, eggs, sodas and cans.

location.town: Los Lobos Segunda Seccion, San Jose del Rincon

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is 29 years old. He is married with 3 children, aged between 3 months and 6 years; one of them goes to school. He is a farmer and he has been producing rice for 10 years. His wife is also a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizers to grow rice and sell them. The profits from the business will be used to pay more workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow rice and sell them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow for milk production and to supply more milk to sell, which will enable her to improve her living standards.

loans.name: Emile

texts.en:
Emile is 23 years old. He is not married. He is a farmer and has been producing rice for seven years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy more fertilizers to grow rice and to sell the rice. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to grow rice and to sell the rice

loans.name: Christabelah's Group

texts.en:
Christabelah is a 32-year-old proud mother of 6 children. She is a group leader, often described as a very hardworking individual, and she is representing her group of 8 farmers in Kakamega North District. Since joining One Acre Fund in 2014, Christabelah has noticed that she has learnt a lot from farming trainings.

Christabelah described her harvest as good last year, but she believes she can have a better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. She is very excited to also be purchasing a solar light, apart from fertilizer and maize, because she will now be able to have an overall improved quality of life. With the profits from this season’s harvest, she plans to save more money for the future.

With this loan, Christabelah’s Group will be able to plant a total of 4 acres of land and purchase a total of 5 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Pictured above is Alice, often described as an extremely hardworking individual. She is 25 years old and, as a group leader, she is representing her group of 7 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya.  She is married and has 4 children.

Alice is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund again as this means that she is able to get the best quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds, which is why she decided to join in the first place. Alice says that she is happy to have made that decision because, since she first joined in 2014, she has learnt a lot from farming training, which has improved her day-to-day life significantly. Alice will use the profits from this season to rent more land to cultivate.

The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 3.25 acres. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of 4 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Lali

texts.en: Lali is a 38-year-old married woman, from village Korbouli. She lives with her husband, who works as a private driver. Lali was unable to find any stable work, in spite of her high education. In her region there is a high unemployment rate, but self-employment helps inhabitants to make a living.  So, she decided to start  her own business with a loan but the local credit providers usually demand experience and some stable income from the borrowers.  Lali’s credit requests were rejected several times, as she was unable to satisfy their requirements. She received credit in the framework of a joint initiative of Kiva and Credo - Startup Program that gives people the chance to start or re-start businesses. With the loan, Lali plans to purchase stock of products and equipment and open a general store locally. She will serve clients herself and will generate her own income, which will help her to cover daily costs. She will be very thankful to all Kiva lenders, for giving her a chance to become financially independent and tackle the financial difficulties.

loans.use: To open a general store and get her own income

loans.name: Deonauth

texts.en:
Deonauth is 39 years old and lives together with his wife and two children. He worked for several years at a well- known car center in
Nickerie and has extensive experience in car accessories. In May 2013, he started his own business selling car accessories at his home. Deonauth makes profits and with his savings he has set up a small shop where he sells the accessories. He wants to expand his range and inventories and approaches Seva MFI for a loan of 6,000 SRD. With the profits, he wants
to pay for the education of his children and save for their future.

loans.use: To buy car accessories for resale.

loans.name: Phelistus's Group

texts.en:
Pictured above is Phelistus, often described as an extremely trustworthy person. She is 25 years old and, as a group leader, she is representing her group of 8 farmers in Kakamega North District, Kenya.  She is married and has 2 children.

Phelistus is returning this season to work with One Acre Fund again as this means that she is able to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods, which is why she decided to join in the first place. Phelistus says that she is happy to have made that decision because, since she first joined in 2014, she has learnt a lot from farming training, which has improved her day-to-day life significantly. Phelistus will use the profits from this season to invest in a business.

The group will use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to plant a total of 4.75 acres. Given that some members of the group will also be purchasing a solar light, with this loan, the group will also receive a total of 2 solar lights.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Maisha Bora Self Help Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Phylis; a member of Maisha Bora self help group. She is forty years old, married and a mother of four. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013.
Phylis does vegetable farming on her small family farm. She has benefited much from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa, which has provided training on enterprise and financial management and enabled her to manage her business effectively. She is borrowing from Kiva to buy farm inputs, such as manure and pesticide, to help increase vegetable yields and hence, her business income. This will help her cover basic family needs and pay school fees for her children. 
She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as manure and pesticide that will boost farm output.

loans.name: Jackleen's Group

texts.en:
Jackleen's Group is formed by 8 farmers in Kakamega North District and is being represented by Jackleen, who is the group leader pictured above. She is 37 years old and married and she has 4 children. Jackleen has been a farmer for 13 years and is often referred to as a very hardworking individual.

Jackleen isn’t new to One Acre Fund; she actually joined the program in 2014 and has since noticed her life has changed, especially in the sense that she has learnt a lot from farming training ever since. This year, Jackleen will not only get fertilizer and maize seeds as part of her loan, but she will also purchase a solar light. She is very excited about this addition since now she will be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

Using this loan, Jackleen's Group will purchase a total of 6 solar lights and use the farming inputs received to plant a total of 2.75 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light, as well as hybrid seeds and fertilizer to improve harvests of maize.

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn is a 40 year old married woman and a mother of five children. Rosalyn lives with her family in the town of Carles, Iloilo. She has been engaged in the fishing business with her husband for more than three years now. This is the source of their income. Rosalyn is asking to take a loan to buy new fishing nets and a new boat engine. A loan will help Rosalyn and her husband improve their fishing business as well as their income.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and a new boat engine

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 57 years old and widowed. She has 4 children. She has had a dairy and poultry farming business for 15 years and it has been profitable. She will be using the loan to purchase poultry and dairy feeds and hopes this will help increase her income to be able to renovate her rental houses and attract more tenants. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her farming, be successful, and live a good and healthy life.

loans.use: To buy dairy and poultry feeds and get more milk, eggs and chicken for sell and increase her overall income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new boat engine

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline, a married mother of three, has been operating a tailoring shop where she makes clothes for five years. Her business has a good location, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

With previous loans repaid, Jackline is now requesting her third from SMEP Microfinance Bank for Kes 35,000 to buy more tailoring materials. Her business goal is to expand and employ people within five years. She also hopes to eventually start a tailoring school.

loans.use: to buy more tailoring materials

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy, a married mother of three children with ages ranging from nine to 20 years, describes herself as focused. For 10 years Lucy has been operating a retail business where she sells sugar, rice, flour, bread and other items. Her business is located in a productive place, but she describes her biggest  challenge to be inadequate capital. 

With her previous loans repaid, Lucy is requesting her third from SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the Kes 70,000 loan to buy more flour, bread, sugar, washing soap and other items. Her business goal is to expand within five years.

loans.use: to buy more flour, bread, sugar, washing soap and other items

loans.name: Freedom Group

texts.en:
These ladies are part of the Freedom Group, which is beginning its ninth cycle with ID Ghana. It is made of three members, and it is represented by Setina. The businesses that the members of the communal association have are varied. Among them are: selling underwear, smoked fish, and diapers.

The loan that they took out will benefit the small micro-entrepreneurs where Setina is a member. She says that four years ago she joined ID Ghana, joining by the invitation of a neighbor who is a member of the institution. Today she has a business selling underwear and diapers.  She started this business five years ago with the support of her mother, who works as a fish seller, and she sells fish with her mother.

The loan that she will take out now is to increase capital (to buy underwear and diapers wholesale) that she will acquire from wholesale venders in the city of Accra, and later she will sell it at the request of the customer. This job allows her to generate resources to support her family economically, since she is single and 30 years old.

When asked about what she likes about ID Ghana, she responds that she likes the saving that the institution offers.

loans.use: To buy underwear and diapers wholesale that she will acquire from wholesale venders in the city of Accra

loans.name: Elguja

texts.en:
Elguja is a 68-year-old pensioner man, from village Orghuli. He lives alone and, except for the pension that he gets from the local government, Elguja generates seasonal income from a vineyard. He takes care with grapes and sells them at the local market. 

This hardworking man has a great desire to start dairy farming and requested a loan to local financial institutions, but his attempts were unsuccessful because of his poor living conditions. 

The startup program which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo enables rural poors to get a loan for starting or re-starting businesses. His application was approved under the framework of this program to get a loan of 1,100 GEL for purchasing 4 sheep. 

Elguja will start milking them and then sell the produced products locally. The loan will greatly assist him and Elguja will be able to improve his economic situation and live better.

loans.use: To start dairy farming and purchase 4 sheep

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima is a married woman and she has two children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a dairy farm where she sells milk. She has been involved in this business for nine years. Her business is located in a productive place and her primary customers are regular. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of animal feed especially during dry season. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy another dairy cow. She hopes that in the future, she will expand her business and educate her children. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy another dairy cow.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria vive en la ciudad de San Pedro con sus padres, ellos le ayudan a solventar los gastos de sus estudios.
Está estudiando la carrera de Licenciatura en Administración Agropecuaria, está en el último año, su objetivo es trabajar en una estancia después de recibirse. 
Pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en el pago de la matrícula de su carrera, y otros gastos de estudios.
texts.en: María lives in the city of San Pedro with her parents, who help her with the costs of her studies.  She is studying for a degree in Agricultural Administration and is in her last year.  Her objective is to work on a ranch after graduating. María is asking for this loan to be able to invest in the payment of tuition for her major and other expenses related to her studies.

loans.use: pay university tuition and other expenses of her studies

loans.name: Ma. Julieta

texts.en:
Ma. Julieta, a 33-year-old woman from Bien Unido, Bohol, is married and has three children. She has been engaged in a fishing business with her husband for more than 10 years now.  

Ma. Julieta is requesting a loan to buy fishing nets, lead weights, hooks and floaters. This loan will help them improve their business as well as their income. 

Ma. Julieta hopes to make their enterprise a success and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, lead weights, hooks and floaters

loans.name: Sadaka

texts.en:
Sadaka is a married woman and she has four children with ages ranging from 2 years to 12 years. She operates a retail business where she sells fish (a small type of fish). She has been involved in this business for 12 years. Her business is located in a busy market and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of fish. Her business goal is to have more shops within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be a fish supplier. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish.

loans.name: Vernecita

texts.en:
Vernecita is a 27-year-old, married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has two children. Vernecita is engaged in a hog raising business. She has raised pigs for several years now. This is the source of her income. 

Vernecita is asking to take a loan to buy piglets to raise and to buy animal feed. Vernecita believes that a loan will help her improve her business as well as her income.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise and to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Las Claveles 33 Group

texts.es:
Martina es una mujer de 32 años, casada, tiene 2 hijos varones de 10 y 14 años y una hija mujer de 19 años, y su negocio es la panadería.
Ella es buena madre, constante, activa, paciente, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla en la localidad de ‘Sacaba’ un área rural que se caracteriza por su crecimiento y por su potencial comercial y productivo. Ubicado en un valle semi-tropical, dónde la venta de comida es abundante, variada y todo se acompaña con chicha (bebida fermentada de maíz). De clima templado durante todo el año.
Martina es de tez morena, cabello negro largo, lo usa trenzado, ojos obscuros, baja estatura, complexión física delgada, viste de forma tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua materna es el Quechua que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que realiza (sentada a la izquierda, usa chompa blanca y mandil rosado). Su vida la comparte con su esposo que se dedica al mismo negocio y con sus hijos; los menores estudian en la escuela y la hija mayor estudia en un instituto técnico, viven en una casa construida de adobe con techo de calamina que cuenta con agua de pozo y electricidad. La necesidad por abastecer los requerimientos de su familia la llevó a formar una banca de personas con negocios como; carpintería, salteñería, venta de cosméticos por catálogo, venta de chamarras, transporte libre, venta de comida y tienda de barrio, para solicitar un préstamo y ampliar sus actividades. Su negocio es la panadería. El olor a pan fresco domina una de las calles del poblado, proviene de una de las panaderías más reconocidas del lugar, el piso está regado de cientos de panes y canastas; en medio resalta la panadera, que muestra las enormes sarnas, similares a pizzas  que son elaboradas con harinas de trigo y blanca, leche, queso y manteca; “Pruebe, va a saber por qué somos conocidísimas”, invita. Su sueño es tener una panadería con varios hornos y panaderos que hagan su trabajo para ella poder descansar, ella desea realizar la compra de variedades de harina por quintal; harina de trigo, de maíz y de arroz. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 20 años que viene realizando esta labor de forma independiente. 
Es por esos motivos que Martina solicita un préstamo para la compra de variedades de harina para hornear mayor cantidad de pan y llegar a más clientes.
texts.en:
Martina is a 32-year-old woman. She is married and has 2 sons, who are 10 and 14 years old, and one daughter, who is 19 years old. Her business is a bakery.

She is a good mother, dependable, active, patient, responsible, and hard working. Her business is located in “Sacaba,” a rural area that is characterized by its growth and by its commercial and productive potential. It is located in a semi-tropical valley, where food sales are abundant, diverse, and always accompanied with “chicha” (a fermented corn drink). The area has a mild climate the whole year. 

Martina has brown skin, long black hair that she wears braided, dark eyes, a short stature, and a thin physique. She wears traditional clothing (hat, blanket, and skirt). Her mother tongue is Quechua, which she speaks at home, and she speaks Spanish for daily life and for her work. In the picture, she is seated at the left, wearing a white sweater and pink apron.

She shares her life with her husband, who does the same work she does, and with her children. The young children study in school, and the older daughter studies in a technical institution. They live in a house built from adobe, with a roof made of corrugated iron; their house has well water and electricity. 

Her need to provide for the needs of her family brought her to form a group with people who have business like: doing carpentry, selling meat pie, selling cosmetics by catalog, selling jackets, offering transportation, selling food, and a neighborhood store. She does this to request a loan and to grow her work. 

Her business is a bakery. The aroma of fresh bread takes over one of the streets of the area. The floor is scattered with hundreds of breads and baskets. In the middle of this, her bakery stands out. It displays the large “sarnas,” which are similar to pizza, made of wheat and white flour, milk, cheese, and butter. She says that once someone tries a “sarna,” they come to understand why her bakery is well known.

Her dream is to have a bakery with many ovens and bakers who do her work for her so that she can rest. She wants to buy different varieties of flour by the quintal, including wheat, corn, and rice flours. This is her first sequence of loans with the institution in the 20 years she has been doing this work independently.

It is for these reasons that Marina requests a loan to buy varieties of flour to bake more bread and have more clients.

loans.use: to buy varieties of flour to bake more bread and have more clients.

loans.name: Norman

texts.en:
Norman is a married man. He operates a retail business where he sells tealeaves. He has been involved in this business for 14 years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital and transport. 

He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of tealeaves. He hopes that in the future, he will his expand business. This is his sixth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tealeaves.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice has four children ranging in age from three to 12 years. The operator of a dairy farm for seven years, Beatrice describes herself as focused. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. 

Her previous loan repaid, Beatrice is requesting her second one from SMEP Microfinance Bank for Kes 40,000 to buy a dairy cow. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman and she has four children with ages ranging from 2 years to 18 years. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells coconuts. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a busy market and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the KES 40,000 loan to hire coconut harvesters and a pickup for transporting coconuts. Her business goal is to be a leading coconut supplier within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to hire coconut harvesters and a pickup for transporting coconuts.

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi is a married woman and she has four children with ages ranging from 9 years to 18 years. She describes herself to be positive. She operates a retail business where she sells fruits and vegetables. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a busy market and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables. Her business goal is to be the main supplier of vegetables within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will create employment for her family. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en: Alberto is a fisherman from Talibon, Bohol. He is 40 years old, married, and has five children. Alberto has been in the business for more than 15 years now. Alberto wants to take a loan to buy a new boat engine, fishing nets, lead weights and floaters. This loan will help him improve his business and income.

loans.use: to buy a new boat engine, fishing nets, lead weights and floaters

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to plaster the walls of her home to conserve her family's health and to install protectors on the doors and windows. Thus, she will offer security in her home.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina is snack food vendor from Getafe, Bohol. She is 48 years old, married, and has five children. Josefina cooks and sells snack foods to the people in her place. This is her source of income for  11 years now. Josefina wants to take a loan to buy ingredients like flour, sugar, milk, cooking oil and others. A loan will help her cook and sell more to her customers.  Josefina dreams of making her business a successful one.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like flour, sugar, milk, cooking oil and others

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
La Sra. Elizabeth vive con sus padres, está en el 3er año de la carrera de Ingeniería Industrial, desea terminar la carrera para generar un mayor ingreso para ella y su familia, de aquí en tres años se ve ejerciendo su carrera como profesional.
Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y emprendedora que se está esforzando por poder ser alguien en la vida.
Pide este préstamo para poder pagar las cuotas de su carrera, y de esa forma poder estar cada vez más cerca de sus metas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elizabeth lives with her parents. She is in her third year of her industrial engineering degree. She wants to finish the degree to generate a better income for her and her family. From this point, in three years, she will be pursuing her career as a professional.

She is a very hard working and enterprising person, who is making an effort to be able to be somebody in her life.

She asks for this loan to be able to pay her tuition. In this way, she will be able to be closer to achieving her goals.

loans.use: to pay her tuition.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, flour, soap, bread and other items to sell.

loans.name: Jocinter

texts.en:
Jocinter is a married woman and she has two children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail shop where she sells vegetables, and eggs. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her primary customers are locals. 

She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of vegetables. She hopes that in the future, she will expand her business. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a farmer from Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has four grown-up children. She grows rice on her farm. Catherine has been in the farming business with her husband for more than 20 years now. She is asking to take a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm. Catherine believes that this loan will help her improve her business as well as her income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a married woman with two children. She describes herself as trustworthy. For three years, she has operated a tailoring shop where she makes clothes. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more supplies for her business. This is her second loan with Kiva's partner, SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She hopes that in the future, she will expand her business.

loans.use: buy more supplies for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is a married woman. She has one child. She operates a retail business where she sells rice, beans, flour, bread and other items. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in a strategic place and her primary customers are locals. 

Jacinta describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the Kes 100,000 loan to buy more stock of rice, bread, flour, sugar and other items. Her business goal is to expand her business to wholesale within five years. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice, bread, flour, sugar and other items

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be a risk taker. She operates a retail business where she sells ice cream. She has been involved in this business for three years. 

Ruth's business is located in a busy place and her primary customers are school children. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy more stock of ingredients for making ice cream. She hopes that in the future, she will have improved profits and better living standards. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to  buy more stock of ingredients for making ice cream

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of beauty products for salon use.

loans.name: Tarini Group

texts.en:
This group is named Tarini and was formed in January 2015 by 11 active and self-dependent women of Panimunda village with an objective for developing their existing businesses. All the members of this group do their own businesses. Mohini is one of them. 

The lady sitting in the middle  of the front row in the photo, wearing the yellow saree,  is Mohini. She is 25 years old and living with her husband and two children. Mohini has been doing a Goat Business from her own home of Panimunda village for the last five years. She sells goats. She also sells goats to the meat suppliers at the market. She earns a monthly income of 7,000 INR. 

Mohini says, although she is earning a handsome income, it is not sufficient to maintain the family, invest in the business, and materialize her dreams. So to get more income by expanding her business, Mohini has planned to purchase more goats with the present loan amount. She hopes to save money for construction of a house and to provide better education to her children.

The other 10 members of her group are also doing small enterprises like vegetable vending, milk business, popped rice business, general store and transport business and, with this loan, hope to enhance their livelihoods.

loans.use: to purchase goats

loans.name: Josefa Jacqueline

texts.es:
El cantón se llama así en honor de la Virgen del Carmen. Posee una considerable riqueza en flora y fauna, siendo una de las fuentes principales de ingreso el cultivo del plátano de la variedad Barraganete.
En este lugar vive la señora Josefa,  tiene 23 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos pequeños. El cónyuge es oficial de un bus. Viven en casa arrendada.
Doña Josefa es una mujer muy luchadora y que para ayudar con los gastos del hogar puso un Bar en un local frente al parque del Carmen, ella vende batidos de frutas y otros productos elaborados. Trabaja todos los días  de 7h00 a 23h00 o hasta que se termine lo que se preparó. Trabaja con la ayuda de su mamá ya que son socias del negocio.  Tiene tres años  a esta actividad y le va muy bien. Ella también vende ropa y zapatos por catálogos hace año y medio en los tiempos libres, trabaja tres días a la semana de dos a tres horas  diarias, ella deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada ocho días,  lo que más vende son sandalias.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa interior y zapatos.  Tiene un año y medio en el grupo de crédito, le gusta el apoyo de las socias, de la fundación le gustan los créditos que son fáciles y sin tantos documentos.
texts.en:
The Canton of Carmen, where señora Josefa lives is named in honor of the Virgen del Carmen. It possesses considerable wealth of flora and fauna. One of the principle sources of revenue is the cultivation of the Barraganete variety of banana.

Josefa is 23 years old and is in a free union from which she has two small children. Her husband is the driver’s assistant on a bus. They live in a rented house.
Doña Josefa is a determined woman and to help with the household expenses, she set up a bar in a spot facing the city park. She sells fruit smoothies and other products that she makes. She works every day from seven am to 11 pm or until she runs out of what she has prepared. She works with the help of her mother, since they are partners in the business. She has had this business for three years and it is going well. She also has been selling clothing and shoes for a year and one-half in her spare time, working three days a week for two or three hours a day. She sells her products on credit and collects payments every week. The items that sell best are sandals.

The purpose of this loan is to buy underwear and shoes. Josefa has been in the credit group for a year and one-half. She likes the support of the members and she also likes that the loans from the foundation are easy to apply for and without so much red tape.

loans.use: to buy undergarments and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of beauty products, caps, vacuum flasks and other items

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a married woman with four children. She describes herself as honest. For five years, she has operated a farm where she grows cabbages and potatoes. Her business is located in a fertile place, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy farm inputs. Her business goal is to expand within five years. This is her first loan with Kiva's partner, SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a married mother of 2 children aged 1 and 3 years. She lives in Bohol, Philippines and earns a living by providing manicure and pedicure services. 

Fatima has been in this business for more than 4 years now. She is requesting a loan to buy more materials such as a nail cutter, nail polish, polish remover, alcohol, etc. 

With this loan Fatima will be able to cater to more customers and thus augment her income. She dreams of improving her livelihood in the future.

loans.use: to buy more materials such as a nail cutter, nail polish, polish remover, alcohol, etc.

loans.name: Katherine Adriana

texts.es:
El cantón se llama así en honor de la Virgen del Carmen. Posee una considerable riqueza en flora y fauna, siendo una de las fuentes principales de ingreso el cultivo del plátano de la variedad Barraganete.
En este lugar vive la señora Katherine, tiene 23 años de edad, es madre soltera de una niña  de 3 años de edad. Ella vive en casa de sus padres. 
Doña Katherine estudia Contabilidad y Auditoría pero para obtener  recursos para los gastos del hogar se dedica a la venta de zapatos por catálogo y trabaja en una boutique de 9h00 a 18h00 como asesora de ventas. Ella aprovecha sus conocimientos en ventas en su negocio, vende en sus tiempos libres  sandalias, zapatos tanto para caballeros como para damas, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada ocho días. Tiene unos meses a esta actividad y le va muy bien, lo que más vende son las sandalias para damas.
Este crédito es para comprar sandalias de promoción y obtener buenas ganancias. Está en el Grupo De Crédito hace seis meses aproximadamente. Agradece el apoyo de la fundación con el seguro de socio seguro y a sus compañeras que son unidas y se apoyan
texts.en:
The Canton of Carmen, where Katherine lives, is named in honor of the Virgen del Carmen. It possesses a considerable wealth of flora and fauna. One of the main sources of revenue is the cultivation of the Barraganete variety of banana.

Katherine, 27, is a single mother of a 3-year-old daughter. She lives in her parents' home.

Katherine studies Accounting and Auditing, but to generate income for household expenses, she sells shoes by catalog and works in a boutique from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. as a sales associate. She uses her knowledge of sales in her business. In her free time, she sells sandals and shoes for both men and women. She sells her products on credit and collects payment every 8 days. She has had this business for a few months and it is going well. The item that sells best is women's sandals.

This loan will be used to buy sandals and to generate good profits. She has been with the communal bank for approximately 6 months. She is grateful for the foundation's support with partner security and for her companions, who are close-knit and support each other.

loans.use: to buy sandals.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix is a carpenter and furniture maker from Talibon, Bohol. He has been in the business for more than 8 years now.

Felix is asking to take a loan to buy more materials like a hammer, nails, plywood, wood and others. With this, he will be able to produce more furniture which he can sell to the market for a good price.

loans.use: to buy more materials like a hammer, nails, plywood, wood and others

loans.name: Jennifer Karina

texts.es:
El cantón se llama así en honor de la Virgen del Carmen. Posee una considerable riqueza en flora y fauna, siendo una de las fuentes principales de ingreso el cultivo del plátano de la variedad Barraganete.
En este lugar vive la señorita Jennifer,  tiene 22  años de edad, es soltera y vive en casa de sus padres.    
Doña Jennifer para obtener sus recursos y con esto ayudar con los gastos del hogar se dedica a trabajar en una fábrica de frituras (papas, yucas, chifles) donde gana el sueldo básico, el horario de trabajo es variado desde las 8h00 hasta la madrugada muchas veces, también tiene días libres. Ella le ayuda a su mamá que tiene un comedor en la atención a los clientes y su papá que vende mariscos en el mercado.  Les va muy bien en estos negocios,  lo que más venden son los almuerzos y mariscos.
Este crédito es para ayudarles a los papás, va a comprar pescado, conchas y camarones para el papá  y víveres para el comedor de su mamá. Tiene un año en el  Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos emergentes son rápidos y por el seguro de salud que ofrece la fundación.
texts.en:
The Canton of Carmen, where Jennifer lives, is named in honor of the Virgen del Carmen. It possesses a considerable wealth of flora and fauna. One of the main sources of revenue is the cultivation of the Barraganete variety of banana.

Jennifer, 22, is single and lives with her parents. To generate income and help with the household expenses, Jennifer works at a fried foods factory (potato, yucca, Chifles brand snacks) where she earns minimum wage. Her work schedule varies from 8:00 until the early morning many times. She also has days off. She helps her mom, who has a restaurant, with customer service and helps her dad, who sells seafood at the market. These businesses are doing very well. The items that sell the best are lunches and seafood.

This loan will be to used to help her parents. She will buy fish, shellfish, and shrimp for her dad and food for her mom's restaurant. She has been with the communal bank for a year and she likes it because the loans are fast and because of the health insurance offered by the foundation.

loans.use: to buy buy fish, shellfish, shrimp and groceries.

loans.name: Bienvinido

texts.en:
Bienvinido is a 44-year-old tricycle driver from Talibon, Bohol. He is married and has been engaged in the business for more than 12 years now.

Bienvinido is asking to take a loan to buy spare parts like a wheel tire, chains, bolts, fuel and others. This loan will help Bienvinido improve his business as well as his income.

loans.use: to buy spare parts like a wheel tire, chains, bolts, fuel and others

loans.name: Alanita

texts.en:
Alanita is a 32-year-old food vendor from Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has two young children.

Alanita sells processed meat like chorizo or pork sausages. She has been in the business for more than a year now. Alanita is asking to take a loan to buy more chorizo or pork sausages to sell. A loan will help her improve her business as well as her income.

loans.use: to buy more chorizo or pork sausages to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a widowed woman. She has 2 children who are ages 7 and 10 years. She describes herself to be polite.

She operates a retail business where she sells firewood. Josephine has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital.

Josephine will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more stock of firewood. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will educate her children. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of firewood

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour and other items

loans.name: Ines

texts.pt:
A sra Ines tem 32 anos de idade, casada e mae de 02 filhos menores de idade.
 Com o empréstimo pretende comprar duvetes, mantas, fatos, camisas e calças para revender e ajudar o seu marido nas despesas do dia-a-dia. O sonho da dona Ines é ter uma loja para passar a vender a sua mercadoria.
O desafio da dona Ines é trabalhar mais de modo a superar as dificuldades financeiras que frequenta
texts.en:
Ines is 32 years old. She's married and has two underage children.
With the loan she intends to purchase comforters, blankets, suits, shirts and pants for re-selling. That way she'll help her husband pay for daily expenses. Ines's dream is to own a store where she can sell her merchandise.
Ines's challenge is working harder in order to overcome the financial hardships she's been facing.

loans.use: to purchase comforters, blankets, suits, shirts and pants for re-selling.

loans.name: Gerald

texts.en:
Gerald is a married father of 5 children with ages ranging from 10 to 26 years. He describes himself as resilient. 

Gerald operates a retail business where he repairs shoes. He has been involved in this business for 20 years now. His business is located in a promising area, and his primary customers are individuals. 

Gerald describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. He will use his 70,000 KES loan to buy more shoe repair supplies. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank, and his previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more supplies of shoe repair materials.

loans.name: Kazosi

texts.en:
Kazosi is a married mother with 2 children. She operates a retail business where she sells omena, a type of small fish. She has been involved in this business for 19 years. 

Kazosi's business is located in a nice place, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge as the rainy season which affects business. 

Kazosi will use her 100,000 KES loan to buy more supplies of fish. Her business goal is to be successful within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will grow her business. 

This is Kazosi's fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more inventory of fish.

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en:
Shadrack, a married father of four, describes himself as visionary. Shadrack has been operating a carpentry business where he makes furniture for 18 years. His enterprise is located in a semi-urban area, and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest challenge as insufficient working capital. 

His previous loan repaid, Shadrack has requested his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank for Kes 100,000 to buy more carpentry materials. His business goal is to have more business outlets within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be successful.

loans.use: to buy more carpentry materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a set of sofas.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.pt:
A senhora  Sandra de 38 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 04 filhos que frequentam o ensino primário e secundário, respectivamente. De salientar que de entre os 04 filhos, 01 não tem idade escolar. 
Com o presente empréstimo será aplicado para a compra de material de construção nomeadamente: cimento, pedra, areia, varrões para dar continuidade na construção da sua casa e, tem como grande desafio  reembolsar o crédito.
texts.en:
Sandra is 38 years old and married. She has four children who attend primary and secondary school, respectively. It should be noted that one of her four children hasn't reached school age yet.
This loan will be used to purchase construction supplies such as cement, rocks, sand and rods, so that she can continue building her house. Her big challenge is repaying the loan.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies such as cement, rocks, sand and rods, so she can continue building her house.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.pt:
O Sr. Antonio de 44 anos de idade, casado e pai de 6 filhos dos quais 2 sao independente, 3 estao a frequentar a escola no ensino primario e secundario e 1 è menor de idade para frequentar escola.
Ele è negociante informal de produtos da 1ª necessidade, actividade que esta a explorar junto com sua esposa no seu estabelicimento comercial juntos com os seus filhos.
Com  presente emprestimo sera aplicado para comprar diversos produtos da 1ª necessidade (arroz, acucar, oleo etc)
Tem como grande desafio aumentar o vulume do seu negocio para garantir a sua reforma e sustento da sua familia.
texts.en:
Antonio is 44 years old and married. He has six children, two of whom are independent, three attend primary and secondary school, and one hasn't reached school age yet.
He's an informal trader of products that are household staples. He conducts this business in his store, alongside his wife and their children.
This loan will be used to purchase several products that are household staples (rice, sugar, cooking oil, etc.).
His great challenge is increasing turnover in his business so that he can pay for house repairs and support his family.

loans.use: to purchase several products that are household staples (rice, sugar, cooking oil, etc.).

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz es una mujer de 47 años de edad, divorciada, tiene un hijo de 11 años, y su negocio es la venta de ropa de segunda mano.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, dinámica, comprometida con su trabajo, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla de forma ambulante en la zona Sur de la ciudad, un área caracterizada por encontrarse enclavadas en las márgenes del majestuoso curso de agua, paseo tradicional del fin de semana, construcciones rústicas con materiales regionales en donde puede degustar la tradicional comida típica y realizar algunas actividades deportivas, de clima frio y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 18-35 grados centígrados.
Beatriz es de tez trigueña, cabello largo castaño lo usa amarrado, ojos obscuros, complexión física delgada, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura  general y por el comercio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su hijo que estudian en la escuela y se dedica al deporte, viven en una casa de la familia construida de ladrillo con techo de calamina que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad y alcantarillado. Su negocio es la venta de ropa de segunda mano. Ella se encarga de comprar ropa por fardos, proveniente de estados unidos, Europa y selecciona la ropa femenina de verano, dejando el resto para la venta de sus familiares, es una actividad que realiza todos los días de la semana en horarios del día. “compro ropa por mayor y escojo la variedad femenina y de verano, porque aquí hace mucho calor, mis clientas ya saben que la ropa que escojo siembre es buena, bonita y barata…” comenta. Su sueño es tener una tienda de ropa para vender en un lugar fijo y dejar de ambular, ella desea realizar la compra de ropa por fardos para incrementar sus ventas y ayudar a pagar material deportivo para la escuela de futbol de su hijo. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 25 años que viene desarrollando esta actividad. 
Es por esos motivos que Beatriz solicita un préstamo para la compra de ropa de segunda mano por fardos y ayudar a pagar el material deportivo que su hijo necesita.
texts.en:
Beatriz is a 47 years old, divorced, and the mother of an eleven-year-old son. She makes a living selling used clothing. Beatriz is a good mother, entrepreneurial, dynamic, committed to her work, responsible, and hard-working. She is a street vendor in the southern part of the city, an area nestled on the shores of the majestic watercourse that is the site of the traditional weekend promenade. There, one can sample traditional foods in rustic buildings made of local materials and engage in some sports. The area has a dry, cold climate and temperatures that fluctuate between 18 and 35 °C daily.

Beatriz has dark skin, dark eyes, and a slim build; she wears her long, dark hair tied back. Beatriz speaks Guaraní—her native language—with her family at home and Spanish for general communication and business. She lives with her son, who is a student and an athlete. They live in a brick family house that has a corrugated metal roof, running water, electricity, and a sewer system. 

Beatriz makes a living selling used clothing. She buys the clothing wholesale from the US and Europe, and re-sells the women's summer clothing herself, while her relatives sell the rest. Beatriz works every day during the daytime. "I buy clothing wholesale and select women's summer clothes because it is very hot here; my customers know that I choose pretty clothes of good-quality and sell them at a low price", she declares. Her dream is to have her own clothing store so she may stop selling in the streets. She would like to buy the clothing wholesale to increase her sales and help pay for the sports equipment that her son needs for soccer lessons. This is the first round of loans with this institution in her 25 years as a street vendor. These are the reasons why Beatriz is requesting a loan to buy used clothing wholesale and help pay for the sports equipment that her son needs.

loans.use: to buy used clothing wholesale and help pay for the sports equipment that her son needs.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a fish vendor from Talibon, Bohol. She is 44 years old and has been in the fish selling business for more than 20 years now. Her husband works as a fisherman.
